revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox organization | name =Lulz Security | bgcolor = | fgcolor = | image = Lulz Security.svg | image_border = | size = | alt = | caption = Lulz Security logo | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | abbreviation =LulzSec | motto ="The world's leaders in high-quality entertainment at your expense" | formation = May 2011 | type = Hacking | purpose = | headquarters = | region_served = | membership = | leader_title = | leader_name = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]], [[LulzRaft]], [[Operation AntiSec|AntiSec]] | num_staff = | num_volunteers = 6 | budget = | website = [http://lulzsecurity.com/ lulzsecurity.com] | remarks = }} '''Lulz Security''', commonly abbreviated as '''LulzSec''', is a [[hacker (computer security)|computer hacker]] group that claims responsibility for several high profile attacks, including the compromise of user accounts from [[Sony Pictures]] in 2011. The group also claimed responsibility for taking the [[CIA]] website offline.{{cite news|title=LulzSec hackers claim CIA website shutdown|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-13787229|accessdate=17 June 2011|newspaper=BBC |date=16 June 2011}} The group has been described as a "[[cyberterrorism|cyber terrorism group]]" by the [[Arizona Department of Public Safety]] after their systems were compromised and information leaked.{{cite web|url=http://www.azdps.gov/Media/News/View/?p=316|title=DPS Victim of Cyber Attack|date=June 27, 2011|work=Press Release|publisher=Arizona Department of Public Safety|accessdate=1 July 2011}} Other security professionals have applauded LulzSec for drawing attention to insecure systems and the dangers of password reuse.{{cite web|title=Is There a Hacking Epidemic?|url=http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2011/07/is_there_a_hack.html}} It has gained attention due to its high profile targets and the sarcastic messages it has posted in the aftermath of its attacks. At just after midnight ([[British Summer Time|BST]], [[Universal Time|UT]]+01) on 26 June 2011, LulzSec released a "50 days of lulz" statement, which they claimed to be their final release, confirming that LulzSec consisted of six members, and that their website is to be taken down.{{cite news|last=Weisenthal|first=Joe|title=Notorious Hacker Group LulzSec Just Announced That It's Finished|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lulzsec-finished-2011-6|accessdate=25 June 2011|newspaper=[[Business Insider]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=Silicon Alley Insider|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ziS1EJcn|archivedate=25 June 2011}} This breaking up of the group was unexpected. {{cite news | first = Peter | last = Svensson | title = Parting is such tweet sorrow for hacker group | date = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | url = http://www.smh.com.au/technology/security/parting-is-such-tweet-sorrow-for-hacker-group-20110626-1glos.html#ixzz1QSL6wvEC | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | accessdate = 2011-06-29}} The release included accounts and passwords from many different sources. Despite claims of retirement, the group committed another hack against newspapers owned by [[News Corporation]] on 18 July, defacing them with false reports regarding the death of [[Rupert Murdoch]]. The [[London Metropolitan Police]] has announced the arrests of two teenagers they allege are LulzSec members [[T-flow]] and [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]]. The group helped launch [[Operation AntiSec]], a joint effort involving LulzSec, [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]], and other hackers. == Overview == LulzSec draws its name from the [[neologism]] "[[Lulz]]", (from [[LOL]]s), "laughing out loud", which often signifies laughter at the victim of a prank, and "Sec," short for "Security". The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' has characterized its attacks as closer to Internet pranks rather than serious cyber-warfare, while the group itself claims to possess the capability of stronger attacks.{{cite news|title=LulzSec threatens governments|date=21 June 2011|work=RT|url=http://rt.com/usa/news/lulzsec-government-group-reads|accessdate=22 June 2011}} It has gained attention in part due to its brazen claims of responsibility and lighthearted taunting of corporations that have been hacked. It frequently refers to [[Internet meme]]s when defacing websites. The group first emerged in May 2011, and has successfully attacked the websites of several major corporations. It specializes in finding websites with poor security, and then stealing and posting information from them online. It has used well-known straightforward methods, such as [[SQL injection]], to attack its target websites. Several media sources have described their tactics as [[grey hat]] hacking.{{cite news|title=Q&A: Lulz Security|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-13671195|accessdate=6 June 2011|newspaper=BBC |date=6 June 2011}}{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Dan|title=Yet another hack, yet another delay in reporting it|url=http://tech.fortune.cnn.com/2011/06/09/yet-another-hack-yet-another-delay-in-reporting-it/?section=magazines_fortune|accessdate=11 June 2011|newspaper=CNN Money|date=9 June 2011}}{{cite news|last=Raywood|first=Dan|title=Security expert publicly backs 'grey hats' such as LulzSec, saying that public disclosure will help businesses|url=http://www.scmagazineuk.com/security-expert-publicly-backs-grey-hats-such-as-lulzsec-saying-that-public-disclosure-will-help-businesses/article/204904/|accessdate=11 June 2011|newspaper=SC Magazine|date=10 June 2011}} Members of the group may have been involved in a [[Anonymous (group)#Attack on HBGary Federal|previous attack]] against the security firm [[HBGary]].{{cite news|last=Acohido|first=Byron|title=Who's who among key LulzSec hackitivists|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2011/06/whos-who-among-key-lulzsec-hackitivists/1|work=USA Today|accessdate=21 June 2011|date=20 June 2011}} The group has used the motto "Laughing at your security since 2011!" and its website, created in June 2011, plays the theme from ''[[The Love Boat]]''.{{cite news|last1=Morse|last2=Sherr|first1=Andrew|first2=Ian|title=For Some Hackers, The Goal Is Just To Play A Prank|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110605-702801.html|accessdate=6 June 2011|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|page=B1|date=6 June 2011}} It announces its exploits via Twitter and its own website, often accompanied with lighthearted [[ASCII art]] drawings of boats. Its website also includes a [[Bitcoin]] donation to help fund its activities.{{cite news|last=Olson|first=Parmy|title=LulzSec Hackers Post Sony Dev. Source Code, Get $7K Donation|url=http://blogs.forbes.com/parmyolson/2011/06/06/lulzsec-hackers-posts-sony-dev-source-code-get-7k-donation/|accessdate=7 June 2011|newspaper=Forbes|date=6 June 2011}} Although exact motivation of the group is unknown, Ian Paul of ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'' has written that, "As its name suggests, LulzSec claims to be interested in mocking and embarrassing companies by exposing security flaws rather than stealing data for criminal purposes."Paul, Ian. "[http://www.pcworld.com/article/229316/lulz_boat_hacks_sonys_harbor_faq.html Lulz Boat Hacks Sony's Harbor: FAQ]." ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]''. 3 June 2011. Retrieved on 6 June 2011. The group has also been critical of [[White hat (computer security)|white hat]] hackers, claiming that many of them have been corrupted by their employers. Some in the security community have lauded them for raising awareness of the widespread lack of effective security against hackers.{{cite news|last=Ragan|first=Steve|title=One month later â LulzSec continues their personal brand of comedy|url=http://www.thetechherald.com/article.php/201123/7251/One-month-later-%E2%80%93-LulzSec-continues-their-personal-brand-of-comedy|accessdate=9 June 2011|newspaper=The Tech Herald|date=8 June 2011}} They have also been credited with inspiring [[LulzRaft]], a group which has been implicated in several high-profile website hacks in Canada.{{cite news|last=Beltrame|first=Julian|title=Hacker without a cause scores with Harper 'breakfast incident' hoax|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5haZn2PyOSvxJly0_pPXkakAc52kA?docId=7077370|accessdate=10 June 2011|newspaper=The Canadian Press|date=8 June 2011}} The group's first recorded attack was against [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox.com]]'s website. It claimed responsibility for leaking information, including passwords, altering several employees' [[LinkedIn]] profiles, and leaking a database of [[The X Factor (U.S.)|X Factor]] contestants containing contact information of 73,000 contestants.{{cite web|title=Who is LulzSec, Hacker of PBS? Are they hacking Sony again?|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/155143/20110531/pbs-hacked-lulzsec-lulz-sony.htm|publisher=International Business Times|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite web |last=Poulsen|first=Kevin|title=Sony Hit Yet Again; Consumer Passwords Exposed|url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/06/sony-lulzsec/|publisher=Wired|accessdate=3 June 2011}} They claimed to do so because the rapper [[Common (entertainer)|Common]] had been referred to as "vile" on air.{{cite news|title=A Brief History of the LulzSec Hackers|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2011/06/21/brief-history-lulzsec-hackers/|accessdate=21 June 2011|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=21 June 2011|agency=[[News Corporation]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zbwTf458|archivedate=21 June 2011|location=New York City}} The group has begun taking suggestions for sites to hit with [[denial-of-service attack]]s.{{cite news|last=Boscker|first=Bianca|title=LulzSec Hacker Group Now Taking Requests|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/15/lulzsec-hacker-group-now-_n_877309.html|accessdate=15 June 2011|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=15 June 2011|agency=[[AOL]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zSjErRoF|archivedate=15 June 2011|location=New York City}} The group has also been redirecting telephone numbers to different customer support lines, including the line for [[World of Warcraft]], magnets.com, and the FBI [[Detroit]] office. The group claims this sends five to 20 calls per second to these sources, overwhelming their support officers.{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=LulzSec Call-In Line Taking Hacking Requests|url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2386959,00.asp|accessdate=15 June 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=15 June 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zSt1Dwzi|archivedate=15 June 2011}} On 24 June 2011, ''[[The Guardian]]'' released leaked logs of the one of the group's IRC chats, revealing that the core group is a small group of hackers with a leader Sabu who exercises large control over the group's activities. It also reveals that the group has connections, though is not formally affiliated with, [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]]. Some LulzSec members had once been prominent Anonymous members, including member [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]]. At just after midnight (GMT) on 26 June 2011, LulzSec released a "50 days of lulz" statement, which they claimed to be their final release, confirming that LulzSec consisted of six members, and that their website is to be taken down.{{cite news|last=Weisenthal|first=Joe|title=Notorious Hacker Group LulzSec Just Announced That It's Finished |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lulzsec-finished-2011-6|accessdate=25 June 2011|newspaper=[[Business Insider]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=Silicon Alley Insider|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ziS1EJcn|archivedate=25 June 2011}} The group claimed that they had planned to be active for only fifty days from the beginning.{{cite news|last=Moyer|first=Edward|title=Hacking group LulzSec says it's calling it quits|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20074416-83/hacking-group-lulzsec-says-its-calling-it-quits/|accessdate=26 June 2011|newspaper=[[CNET.com]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zifBaJXe|archivedate=26 June 2011}} "We're not quitting because we're afraid of law enforcement. The press are getting bored of us, and we're getting bored of us." a group member said in an interview to [[The Associated Press]].{{cite news|last=Svensson|first=Peter|title=Hacker group LulzSec says it's disbanding|url=http://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2011-06-26-lulzsec-disbands_N.htm|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=26 June 2011|agency=[[The Associated Press]]}} Members of the group have been reported to have joined with Anonymous members to continue the AntiSec operation.{{cite news|last=Olivarez-Giles|first=Nathan|title=AntiSec 'hackers without borders' claim new hack on Arizona state police|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/06/antisec-hackers-leak-files-said-to-be-from-arizona-state-police.html|accessdate=30 June 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=29 June 2011|agency=[[Tribune Company]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zq3OxQQv|archivedate=30 June 2011|location=[[Los Angeles]]}} However, despite claiming to retire, the group attacked the websites of British newspaper ''[[The Times]]'' and ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' on 18 July, leaving a false story on the death of owner [[Rupert Murdoch]]. == Members and associates == LulzSec consists of six core members. The online handles of these six have been established through various attempts by other hacking groups to release personal information of group members on the internet, leaked IRC logs given to ''[[The Guardian]]'', and through confirmation from the group itself.{{cite news|last=Poeter|first=Damon|title=Who Is LulzSec?|url=http://www.pcmag.com/slideshow/story/266414/Who-Is-LulzSec|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=2 July 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zx2jodqN|archivedate=5 July 2011|pages=1â9}} * [[Sabu (hacktivist)|Sabu]] – One of the group's founders who seemed to act as a kind of leader for the group, often Sabu decides what targets to attack next and who could participate in these attacks. He may have been part of the Anonymous group that hacked [[HBGary]]. Various attempts to release his real identity have claimed that he is an [[Information technology consulting|information technology consultant]] with the strongest hacking skills of the group and a knowledge of the [[Python (programming language)|Python]] programming language. * [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]] – Topiary is also a suspected former member of the Anonymous AnonOps, where he used to perform media relations, including hacking the website of the [[Westboro Baptist Church]] during a live interview.{{cite news|last=Goodman|first=William|title=Video: Anonymous hacks Westboro Baptist Church website during on-air confrontation|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504784_162-20036043-10391705.html|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=24 February 2011|agency=[[CBS]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5zx3f5f7H|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}} Topiary ran the LulzSec Twitter account on a daily basis; following the announcement of LulzSec's dissolution, he deleted all the posts on his twitter page, except for one, which stated: "You cannot arrest an idea". http://twitter.com/atopiary Police arrested a man from [[Shetland]], [[United Kingdom]] suspected of being Topiary on 27 July 2011. The man was later identified as Jake Davis and was charged with five counts, including unauthorized access of a computer and conspiracy.{{cite news|title=LulzSec: Shetland teen charged over computer hacking claims|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14359933|accessdate=31 July 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=31 July 2011|agency=[[BBC]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/60b7Z5Nyr|archivedate=31 July 2011|location=[[London]]}} * Kayla – Also identified as "lol" in LulzSec chat logs, Kayla owns a [[botnet]] used by the group in their distributed denial-of-service attacks. The botnet is reported to consist of about 8,000 infected [[computer server]]s. Kayla also may have participated in the Anonymous operation against HBGary. * T-flow – The fourth founding member of the group identified in chat logs, attempts to identify him have labelled him a [[PHP]] coder, [[web developer]], and performer of scams on [[PayPal]]. The group placed him in charge of maintenance and security of the group's website lulzsecurity.com. London Metropolitan Police announced the arrest of a 16 year-old hacker going by the handle Tflow on 19 July 2011. * Avunit – He is one of the core six members of the group, but not a founding member. He left the group after their self-labelled "Fuck the FBI Friday". He was also affiliated with Anonymous AnonOps HQ. * Pwnsauce – Pwnsauce joined the group around the same time as Avunit and became one of its core members. Associates and former members include: * M_nerva – M_nerva, once a member of the group, leaked some of the group's chat logs to ''The Guardian''. In response to the leak, LulzSec published M_nerva's personal information and records of the illegal hacking activity performed with them. May also have participated with LulzSec in the attack on Fox.com. * Joepie91 – Though he is one of the most frequent participants in LulzSec IRC chat logs, the group stated that he is not a core member.. * Neuron – Neuron is not a core member of the group, but may have supported them by building software and taking part in some of their distributed denial-of-service attacks. He is thought to be an engineering student in the [[United States]]. * [[LulzSec#Ryan Cleary|Ryan Cleary]] – A 19-year-old from [[Essex]], [[United Kingdom]] who was arrested by [[Metropolitan Police]] on 21 June 2011 and charged with violating the [[Computer Misuse Act 1990|Computer Misuse Act]] and the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]]. Though not a member of the group, LulzSec admitted that he did run one of the IRC channels that they used for communicating. == Ideology ==
